Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a quantitative real-time gene expression monitoring system for undergraduate research and teaching at Pace University 2016
Award.AbstractNarration:
An award is made to Pace University to acquire a quantitative real-time gene expression monitoring system for use in undergraduate research and teaching. This equipment will support the participation of undergraduate students, with a focus on women and underrepresented minorities, in biological research. Research training utilizing this equipment will allow students to design, execute, and analyze research projects at the cutting edge of biological research in areas that have not yet been fully explored. Additionally, this equipment will allow for the development and testing of a flexible genetics and molecular biology curriculum that is proven to enhance student learning and can be implemented by any institution to facilitate student engagement in discovery-driven research projects.

The students and faculty using this equipment will be answering research questions in a broad range of areas, including how cells divide, how fish and bacteria responds to stress, how viruses survive in the host, and how an organism responds to changes in diet. The answers to these questions will increase students' understanding of basic aspects of ecology, evolution, cancer biology, cell biology, developmental biology, immunology, and microbiology. Moreover, this equipment will support original research to further the understanding of how genes are regulated, thereby providing insight into a variety of biological systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award allowed the Biology Department at Pace University to: 1) develop a productive research environment, 2) to perform discovery-driven research, 3) train students on cutting-edge research equipment, and 4) broaden participation in biology research by women and underrepresented minorities. The project allowed for the purchase of a quantitative PCR system to determine gene expression changes and a fluorometer to quantitate nucleotide and protein samples. Both systems are currently used in both classroom and research lab settings. The supported research laboratory projects allowed department collaborators to determine how Mycobacterium regulates its metabolism in response to drug exposures and how oyster populations respond to stress in different environmental contexts. The faculty collaborators and students who used the equipment are all women. Without the funding support provided by the NSF, these experiments could not have been completed and the students would not have received the training and experience. Currently, faculty are working to develop protocols for classroom use that would allow students at a variety of institution types to perform discovery-driven experiments that produce novel research data. The initial financial support from the NSF has created a productive and supportive research environment that is now sustained by the department and the university.
